titleStmt.title: Lacy's People: a list of the authors credited in Lacy's Acting Edition

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished draft for the Digital Lacy website

sourceDesc.p: Pulled together from a variety of sources

div.head: Preface
div.p: This personography documents every person named on the title page of a Lacy Acting Edition, using a standardised form of their name, and listing the LAE titles for which they are credited as sole or joint author. It also supplies pointers to reference information for the person concerned.
The following biographical sources have been used:

list.label: ATCL
list.item: Link to entry for this person in Troy J. Bassett's "At the Circulating Library: A Database of Victorian Fiction" (http://www.victorianresearch.org/atcl/index.php. Accessed 21 December 2024.
list.label: Boase
list.item: Link to this person's entry Boase, Frederic. Modern English Biography. (either the original version as distributed by Project Gutenberg, or for volumes 3-6 the Cass reprint of 1965)
list.label: DAS
list.item: Person is named as a member of the Dramatic Authors Society, with one or more titles priced in the "Provincial Tariff" (second issue : in force to the 30th June 1879).
list.label: DLB
list.item: Person has a detailed bibliography and biography in Proquest's "Dictionary of Literary Biography" (pay wall)
list.label: Ledger
list.item: Note on this person in the Biographical Memoranda of Living Dramatic Authors contributed by Edward Ledger to the Era Almanac for 1868 or 1869
list.label: ODNB
list.item: Entry for this person in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (paywall)
list.label: VIAF
list.item: Entry for this person in the Virtual International Authority File
list.label: Wikidata
list.item: Wikidata identity of this person, where available
list.label: Wikipedia

person.note: AMHERST, J. H., actor, born in London, England, in 1776; died in Philadelphia, 12 August 1851. He first appeared at the Haymarket theatre, London, in "The Blue Devils." He came to the United States in 1838 as director of Cook's equestrian company, and first acted as the "Castilian" in "Mazeppa" in Philadelphia. After a moderately successful career he fell victim to a complication of diseases, died in the almshouse, and was buried by the actors' order of friendship. He was an accomplished classical scholar, and the author of several plays, of which the following are the best known: "Will Watch, or the Black Phantom" (1825); " Napoleon Bonaparte's Invasion of Russia, or the Conflagration of Moscow" (1850); " Ireland as it Was " (1850) ; " The Battle of Waterloo" (1850): and "Ireland as it Is " (1850).

person.note: Eldest son William Blanchard Jerrold wrote Life and Remains of Douglas Jerrold (1859); also edited The Wit and Opinions of Douglas Jerrold (1858), and The Works of Douglas Jerrold, with a memoir by his son, W. B. Jerrold, in 1863–64, which was never completed. See also Michael Slater. Douglas Jerrold: A Life (1803–1857).
